title: Benchmark: Tao's symplectic integration method
authors: Matheus Lazarotto, Iber\^e Caldas, Yves Elskens
abstract:
A benchmark test was conducted for a new symplectic integration method
originally developed by Molei Tao. The method raises interest due to its
explicit evolution equation, with applicability to both separable and
non-separable Hamiltonian systems, and an easy-to-implement, easily
generalizable algorithm. In order to compare the method with other, more
well-known methods, namely St\"{o}rmer-Verlet and Runge-Kutta, we conducted a
series of benchmark tests comparing their performance in terms of CPU time,
system invariants functions conservation, and numerical symplectic area
conservation. Overall, it was found that despite being slower than the more
optimized Runge-Kutta-Cash-Karp, Tao's method presents a similar performance to
St\"{o}rmer-Verlet, with the extra perk of being more generic and not requiring
the use of implicit equations for the evolution of the equations of motion.
